data.title: Add highlight decorations
data.body:
This adds the ability to highlight ranges in the buffer tracked by markers. Just like find and replace does when you search for something, only more efficient. You write a little code:

``` coffee
marker = editor.markBufferRange([[4, 13], [5, 17]], invalidate: 'inside')
editor.addDecorationForMarker(marker, type: 'highlight', class: 'sweet-view')

marker = editor.markBufferRange([[12, 16], [12, 19]], invalidate: 'inside')
editor.addDecorationForMarker(marker, type: 'highlight', class: 'sweet-view')
```

``` css
.sweet-view .region {
  border-radius: 2px;
  background: rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.5);
}
```

And get this:
![screen shot 2014-06-17 at 11 46 53 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/3304959/8da0d2dc-f650-11e3-834c-08027ecd98b6.png)
### Changes

Some things changed from the previous iteration of decorations
- All decorations are marker based. It made storage and rendering easier. There are 2 functions on editor that you need to be concerned with: `addDecorationForMarker` and `removeDecorationForMarker`
- There are no more typeless decorations. You can apply to multiple decoration types by using an array: `{type: ['gutter', 'line'], class: 'sweet-view'}`
- Rather than an option to handle softWrapped lines in gutter / line types, you specify a range of `[[4, 0], [4, Infinity]]` to apply it to the wrapped rows, and `[[4, 0], [4, 0]]` to only apply to the initial row. 

See #2507 for the original decorations

data.title: Using umlauts in keymaps
data.body:
``` coffee
'body':
  'cmd-ä': 'pane:show-next-item'

'body':
  'cmd-ö': 'pane:show-previous-item'
```

`cmd-ä` is ignored while `cmd-ö` correctly triggers `show-previous-pane`.  It appears `ä` and `ö` are treated as the same keys.

Atom 0.103.0, Mac OS 10.9.3.

data.title: Provide a simpler way to act on files by extension
data.body:
A very common question in IRC is "How can I make files with some extension set a certain behavior / use a certain grammar". As far as I know the state of the art is to put something like this in `user.coffee`:

``` coffeescript
atom.workspaceView.eachEditorView (editorView) ->
  editor = editorView.getEditor()
  if path.extname(editor.getPath()) is '.md'
    editor.setSoftWrap(true)
```

Perhaps we could provide some syntactic sugar nicer than iterating over every EditorView, like say an object of path matchers and functions that get the current editor added to their context and run when initializing a new editor?

``` coffeescript
atom.fileActions = #terribly named
  '\.md$': -> currentEditor.setSoftWrap(true)
```

Along the same lines it might be worth encouraging configurable file types in packages like e.g. atom/language-c

data.title: Select all + backspace doesn't always delete everything.
data.body:
Selecting everything in a file and quickly pressing backspace doesn't delete everything as it's supposed to, but leaves the last line of the selection untouched. Here's a demo: 

![atom-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2262772/3260452/57b398e0-f24e-11e3-8d97-030857f51582.gif)

The first `cmd+a+backspace` is very quick, and the last line stays in the editor. The second one has a ~1 second pause between `cmd+a` and `backspace`, and everything gets deleted as expected. Everything works fine on the third time too, which is mildly surprising since the pause is quite brief. On the fourth time the bug resurfaces again and nothing gets deleted, since the only line in the selection is the last (and first) line.

data.title: Delete file causes crash, erases project and rolls back to an earlier "cached" version
data.body:
I don't have much in the way of debugging information.  

MacBook Air, Atom v0.99.0
- I right clicked on a file and selected "delete".  
- Window pops up asking if I want to delete or move to trash.  I select Delete
- Main editor window partially blanks out and a firebug window opens on the bottom third of the screen.  Firebug window is empty, scrolling in main window remains blank.
- I restart Atom, since this has happened before (seems like just a UI painting problem)
- Upon restarting, my entire project has been "reset" to an earlier version, perhaps several days ago.  I can only assume that Atom maintains a cache somewhere and upon crash decided to restore from this...instead of just leaving the files alone.
- Strangely, some newly created files (from tonight) remain 100% intact.  It's just the files that I've been editing for the last several days that were overwritten with a much earlier version.

I was just hacking around on my laptop and hadn't started a git repo yet, soo...Atom effectively nuked my project.  

Not really a big deal (other than being irritating) but this is certainly a frightening behavior.  Deleting or corrupting files is one thing, but completely overwriting an entire project wholesale is scary. :(

data.title: Handle textInput events in a way that works with autocomplete-plus
data.body:
Fixes #2318

This commit also changes input handling to be more like it was in the previous editor. We're using textInput rather than input events because they are emitted _before_ characters are inserted, enabling much simpler detection of characters inserted via the accented-character menu on OS X.

We're also handling these events on the editor instead of the input component, which allows events to bubble from autocomplete-plus's hidden input element.

Previously I avoided this because something about it was causing reflows in the old editor, but in this editor that doesn't seem to be a problem, and it's actually faster.

data.title: HTML script tag does not use HTML comments
data.body:
```
<script src="script.js"></script>
```

On the above line of HTML, using CMD + / to comment the line produces this:

```
// <script src="script.js"></script>
```

Applying CMD + / again produces this:

```
<!-- // <script src="script.js"></script> -->
```

And, applying CMD + / once more will toggle the HTML comments.

The expected behavior would be to treat the script tag as any other HTML tag.

data.title: Outdent only if a tab is matched at the start of the line
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2560. 

When outdenting, the `leadingTabRegex` currently matches spaces only at the beginning of the line, while tabs are matched anywhere in the line. As a result, the outdent method would eat up legit characters on lines which contain tabs after the beginning of the line.

This change tweaks the regex so that tabs are matched only at the beginning of the line.

cc @probablycorey @kevinsawicki
